emailColumn.title: orbita: Telematics Market Entry Strategy in Brazil

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Alexey Belyaev is a project manager and business development expert who led orbita's international expansion into the Brazilian telematics market. With experience in market research, strategic planning, and cross-cultural business operations, Alexey guided the company through the complex process of establishing operations in Latin America.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: This case study reveals the challenges of international market entry in the telematics industry. Key lessons include: 1) The critical importance of quality market research - outdated data from 2009 significantly delayed the project. 2) Budget flexibility is essential when entering unknown markets - initial costs are unpredictable until on-ground research is conducted. 3) Local presence is crucial for understanding market dynamics - remote planning has limitations. 4) Clear decision-making structures prevent delays, though this project benefited from streamlined leadership. 5) Branding and legal setup must happen simultaneously to avoid bottlenecks. The Brazil telematics market shows strong growth potential with 15% CAGR, making it an attractive target despite entry challenges.

emails.body:

The situation with opening the bank account ğŸ¦ was indeed one of our initial challenges. Your team helped us find lawyers âš–ï¸, and they found pretty good ones in the end. I created a Gantt chart ğŸ“… for the project practically from the very beginning, outlining what we needed to accomplish and the timeline. highlight.title: Having a Clear Vision From Day One
highlight.description: Even though the details weren't perfect, knowing exactly what product you want to sell (telematics security systems) and having some initial market knowledge (1000+ cars already equipped) gives you a strong foundation. It's like knowing you want to open a pizza restaurant - you might not know the exact menu yet, but you know your basic direction.

emails.subject: Project Vision and Strategic Direction
emails.body:
You inquired about the specific goals that were set for me when I joined this project and what the overall mission looked like.

The task was straightforward but ambitious. Our initial partners were busy with other projects and didn't have the resources to invest into our new venture, so we decided to open our own operations and develop there ourselves. The goal was to make a full-fledged enterprise there. I was told: "Alexey, here are consultants for you, figure it out, and let's start working with them." ğŸ’¼

One of the first tasks was to build a comprehensive plan and schedule ğŸ“‹. Most importantly, we needed to figure out the market information because I didn't know Portuguese well enough initially. While I can read everything now and understand it all, I hadn't managed to learn to speak it properly at that time.

The project plan included looking for local people ğŸ‘¥ and engaging in various promotional activities. Everything was written out in principle. The only thing that changed later was essentially the timelines, and only at the very end did the project stop for reasons unrelated to the consulting work.

There was a deadline initially - we wanted to time this to an event in September 2023 ğŸ“…, some kind of automotive exhibition where they display cars ğŸš—, similar to what used to happen at home. We didn't make that deadline for various reasons, but later we understood we needed more time anyway. When this moved to 2024, we had some periods where we stopped for almost a whole month â±ï¸, particularly twice in the summer.

highlight.title: Starting With Confidence and Flexibility
highlight.description: Sometimes the best approach is to trust your team and give them clear authority to make decisions. When the CEO says 'figure it out with the consultants,' it shows confidence in the project manager. Also, missing deadlines isn't always bad - sometimes you discover you need more time to do things properly.

emails.subject: Budget Planning and Financial Framework
emails.body:
I wanted to address your question about whether we had a clear budget established from the beginning for launching the business in Brazil ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·.

Since initially there were no serious expenses and it wasn't clear what we could sell and to whom, there was no predetermined budget at the start ğŸ’°. I developed something like a strategy for myself - several dozen slides outlining our approach, hardware specifications, and various operational aspects.

The initial budget was essentially just working with your team, plus money ğŸ’µ for various websites ğŸ’» and legal expenses âš–ï¸. The understanding was that when it became clear what kind of business plan we needed, then we would draw up a proper budget.

At some point this became clearer, but honestly, it only became fully clear when I arrived in Brazil âœˆï¸. From Moscow, it's quite difficult to imagine the specifics. When I was actually in Brazil, I sat down and created a clearer Excel spreadsheet ğŸ“Š with a proper business plan - outlining how much we needed to sell, what the break-even point would be, and what Brazilians were generally interested in. I had preliminary versions before this, of course, but the real clarity came from being on the ground ğŸŒ.

highlight.title: Sometimes You Can't Plan Everything From Your Office
highlight.description: It's impossible to create a perfect budget when you don't know the market yet. It's like trying to plan a grocery budget for a country you've never visited - you need to actually go there and see what things cost. Starting with basic expenses (consultants, websites, legal) and building the detailed budget once you understand the market is often the smart approach.

emails.subject: Market Research Expectations and Challenges
emails.body:
You were asking about what I most hoped to get from the research.

I expected to receive marketing research in the most traditional, comprehensive form ğŸ“‹. Something showing the telematics market and security systems landscape - who the main players were, with the usual diagrams and tables ğŸ“Š. Information about how many cars ğŸš— are sold, how many are insured, whether insurers attach their devices mandatorily or not. Initially, we didn't even know who our customer would be.

There are different types in the automotive sector: car makers ğŸ­, dealers ğŸª, leasing companies. For leasing, if someone takes a car and stops paying, the lessor can press a button ğŸ”˜ so the car doesn't drive anymore, see its location on a map ğŸ—ºï¸, and retrieve it. Security systems vary too - fleet management, freight transport monitoring ğŸš›. We were looking at where we should focus our efforts generally.

After some time, we decided that fleets would probably be more interesting to us initially, possibly freight transport. But we needed that foundational market intelligence to make informed decisions.

The research challenge was significant. We had no understanding of how much competitors' solutions cost ğŸ’°, no idea about subscription pricing models, or what services they offered. At home, for example, simple systems let you view your car from your phone ğŸ“± or open doors remotely. More complex ones let you control the engine and start it in cold weather â„ï¸. Security systems range from basic notifications to full rapid response services with special groups checking on incidents ğŸš¨.

We expected there would be similarities across countries, but we had no concrete understanding even by the beginning of 2024. The information we did get was often based on incomplete assumptions or data from just one company, making it unclear if it was representative of the broader market.

highlight.title: Good Research Should Answer the Basic Questions
highlight.description: Market research should be like a good map - it shows you where you are, where you want to go, and who else is already there. When entering a new market, you need to know: Who are your competitors? How much do they charge? Who are the customers? What do customers actually want? Without this basic information, you're essentially walking in the dark.

emails.subject: Decision-Making Structure and Internal Coordination
emails.body:
You were interested in understanding our internal decision-making process - how we coordinated between team members and who was ultimately responsible for strategic choices.

Practically all decisions I made myself ğŸ¤”. Sometimes I would consult, saying something like "Look, Mikhail (CEO) ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼, here's the situation, here are the options, and I suggest this approach." But generally, they have their own business operations and don't really control my day-to-day activities, so there wasn't constant oversight of what I was doing.

When it came to important discoveries from research ğŸ“Š or branding decisions ğŸ¨, it wasn't that these things didn't interest them - they were just waiting for substantial results rather than getting involved in every operational detail. Another cofounder does like branding discussions and participated in those decisions, but branding is essentially packaging and doesn't significantly affect project timelines or core operations.

There was no discord in our company - no situation where people were pulling in different directions ğŸ¤. Everyone initially understood how this reflected in our plan: we wanted to have our own enterprise with everything ready - legally âš–ï¸, financially ğŸ’°, with a clear business plan ğŸ“‹. They expected to get this from me, most likely after the trip to Brazil âœˆï¸, because developing this remotely was difficult.

The structure worked well because everyone knew their roles and trusted the process we had established.

highlight.title: Clear Authority Makes Everything Faster
highlight.description: When everyone knows who makes which decisions, projects move much faster. It's like having one person drive the car instead of everyone trying to steer at the same time. The CEO trusted Alexey to handle daily decisions and only got involved in big strategic questions. This prevented delays and confusion.

emails.subject: Branding Development and Agency Selection
emails.body:
You asked me to elaborate on how the branding component emerged and why we decided to pursue such comprehensive rebranding efforts.

The branding need appeared practically from the very beginning because we couldn't use our existing company name as it was already in use by our Brazilian partners ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·. If we were going to approach new clients, we needed to have proper business cards ğŸ’³ and a website ğŸ’» immediately so we could discuss our services professionally.

This became an immediate priority. We did delay the branding work somewhat because we initially planned to run a proper tender process, but it was decided internally to work with our existing partners instead.

The delay was also partly because it's difficult to create an effective website when you don't fully understand your target customers yet ğŸ¯. And we couldn't fully understand our target customers partly because the marketing research had outdated data - like that 13-year-old insurance information ğŸ“Š.

I remember the table you compiled with about 10 Brazilian branding agencies ğŸ¢. After evaluating the options, our company leadership decided to use our existing IT partners instead. The decision was practical: "Alexey, why are you looking elsewhere when we have excellent companies that have already created everything for us and our partners? They're right here, we have contracts with them, and we communicate daily because we constantly launch new projects." The fact that they didn't speak Portuguese wasn't considered a problem since they work internationally anyway ğŸŒ.

Honestly, they came up with a great name - orbita â­ - which I really like. It perfectly captured what we were trying to achieve.

highlight.title: Sometimes the Best Choice is Right Next to You
highlight.description: Instead of spending time searching for new suppliers, sometimes it's better to work with people you already trust. The company had great IT partners who understood their business and could work internationally. Plus, choosing 'orbita' as the name was smart - it suggests global reach and technology, perfect for a telematics company.

emails.subject: Branding Implementation and Timeline Management
emails.body:
You wanted to know more details about how I approached the branding agency and what specific requirements we established beyond the basic website and business card needs.

I try to approach such questions systematically ğŸ“‹. I gave them a proper brief stating exactly what I needed: website development ğŸ’», business cards ğŸ’³, overall style guide ğŸ¨, and a company name. I wrote down my ideas and sent a presentation - about five slides ğŸ“Š - emphasizing that we wanted to convey security focus ğŸ”’ and that we had advanced technologies.

Regarding timelines, there was definitely a clear understanding that branding needed to be completed by a specific date â°. We had that original schedule where everything was mapped out. Even though deadlines slipped, we immediately understood this needed to be done right away. You can see in the timeline that it starts immediately after the legal work âš–ï¸ and market research ğŸ“Š phases.

Since the other components had deadlines, branding had to align with those as well. It's clear that things ran into complications along the way, but the agency suggested several excellent options. Orbita â­ turned out to be the best choice among all the possibilities they presented.

The systematic approach helped ensure we got quality results even when timelines shifted.

highlight.title: Being Systematic Gets Better Results
highlight.description: Instead of just saying 'make us look good,' Alexey gave the branding team a clear brief with specific requirements. He explained what the company does (security and advanced technology) and what materials they needed (website, business cards, style guide). This systematic approach helped get better results even when timelines changed.

emails.subject: Research Quality and Implementation Issues
emails.body:
I need to give you honest feedback about how the research of the market processes.

I suggested buying existing research if needed - we weren't against compensating for that ğŸ’°. But what we ended up with was very specific, limited information - like calling some dealer through a friend of a friend to find out what systems they install ğŸ“. These were really narrow data points rather than market intelligence. I found things like insurance data from the second half of 2009 ğŸ“Š - information that was completely outdated and ineffective. This definitely slowed down the project from the very beginning â°.

For future projects like this, it might be more effective to immediately acknowledge when comprehensive market research should be purchased from specialized sources ğŸ¢, with your team helping to identify the best providers. The internet ğŸŒ makes this information quite difficult to find independently, and we spent too long without understanding basic market parameters like pricing structures and competitive landscapes.

Warm regards,

highlight.title: Good Research is Worth Paying For
highlight.description: Using 13-year-old insurance data is like using an old map to navigate a new city - you'll get lost. Sometimes it's better to buy professional market research from experts rather than trying to piece together information from random phone calls. Quality research might cost money upfront, but it saves time and prevents costly mistakes later.
